user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of uh_cb:
```c
static void
uh_cb (void *cls,
       struct MHD_Connection *connection,
       void *req_cls,
       const char *extra_in,
       size_t extra_in_size,
       MHD_socket sock,
       struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh)
{
  struct MyData *md;
  pthread_t pt;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) req_cls;     /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  md = malloc (sizeof (struct MyData));
  if (NULL == md)
    abort ();
  memset (md, 0, sizeof (struct MyData));
  if (0 != extra_in_size)
  {
    md->extra_in = malloc (extra_in_size);
    if (NULL == md->extra_in)
      abort ();
    memcpy (md->extra_in,
            extra_in,
            extra_in_size);
  }
  md->extra_in_size = extra_in_size;
  md->sock = sock;
  md->urh = urh;
  if (0 != pthread_create (&pt,
                           NULL,
                           &run_usock,
                           md))
    abort ();
  /* Note that by detaching like this we make it impossible to ensure
     a clean shutdown, as the we stop the daemon even if a worker thread
     is still running. Alas, this is a simple example... */
  pthread_detach (pt);

  /* This callback must return as soon as possible. */

  /* Data forwarding to "upgraded" socket will be started
   * after return from this callback. */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static void
uh_cb (void *cls,
       struct MHD_Connection *connection,
       void *req_cls,
       const char *extra_in,
       size_t extra_in_size,
       MHD_socket sock,
       struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh)
explanation: I flagged the function parameters and assignments that involve pointer types which appear not to be modified in this function (or which store pointers to data that may be immutable) and thus could require investigation for possible const-qualification. I did not flag other fragments because: (1) extra_in is already const-qualified (const char *extra_in) and therefore complies with Rule 8.13; (2) the local pointer md is written to (its fields are initialized and modified), so md itself and fields that are modified must not be const; (3) the use of pthread_create requires the start routine and its argument as void * by the API, so that call cannot be changed to use a const-qualified pointer without changing the thread API; (4) calls to malloc and memset produce/consume writable memory as used here, so those allocations and writes are appropriate; and (5) other uses of non-pointer scalar types (size_t, MHD_socket) are not relevant to Rule 8.13. Investigate the listed fragments to determine whether parameters or stored pointers (for example connection, cls, req_cls, urh, and md->extra_in) could and should be declared to point to const-qualified types.
